title: 109_s1935
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Fund for Ireland Enhancement Act of 2005". Congress acknowledges the US involvement in the Northern Ireland peace process, supports economic development in the region, and recognizes the strong relationships with Ireland and the UK. The International Fund for Ireland was established in 1986 to aid economic growth in the affected areas. The International Fund supports economic development and peace in Northern Ireland and border areas of the Republic of Ireland. The US has donated over $386 million to improve relations between Catholics and Protestants, creating jobs and business opportunities for them to work together. Over 80% of the Fund's investments target disadvantaged areas, providing job training and work experience for youth. The International Fund supports economic, social, and physical regeneration in Northern Ireland. It promotes dialogue between Catholics and Protestants, develops new leaders, and aims for a peaceful and prosperous future in the region. The US contributions aim to support reconciliation, peace, and a society free from discrimination and terrorism in Northern Ireland. The United States assistance to the International Fund has greatly contributed to economic development and reconciliation in Northern Ireland, aligning with the objectives of the Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986. The Good Friday Agreement of 1998 established the Northern Ireland Executive Assembly and Executive Committee, promoting a democratically elected Assembly for a just and lasting peace in the region. The Good Friday Agreement of 1998 established a democratically elected Assembly in Northern Ireland with executive and legislative authority, police reform, and human rights protection. The Good Friday Agreement of 1998 established an Assembly in Northern Ireland with police reform and human rights protection. In 2002, a report recommended new police training facilities and increased funding for training programs in Northern Ireland. AMENDMENTS TO THE ANGLO-IRISH AGREEMENT SUPPORT ACT OF 1986. It is the sense of Congress that assistance from the United States for the International Fund for Ireland has greatly contributed to economic development in Northern Ireland. Policing reform is crucial for public confidence in the new government, and the International Fund is encouraged to support programs that enhance community relations and police-community relations. The International Fund for Ireland is encouraged to support programs that enhance community relations, promote human rights training for police, and facilitate peaceful mediation in conflict-ridden neighborhoods. Amendments to the Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act emphasize the importance of these initiatives. The Patten Commission recommends partnership police boards and the transition of former British military sites into community-supported activities like housing and commercial development. The United States is authorized to contribute $20,000,000 for each fiscal year in 2006 and 2007 to the International Fund for Ireland. The United States is authorized to contribute $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2006 and 2007 to the International Fund for Ireland. Congress recommends that at least 35 percent of the funds be used for improving local community relations and police-community interactions. Annual reports should reflect these efforts.
